title: Turban squash
text:
Turban squash, also known as "Turk's turban" or "French turban" ("Giraumon" in French), is a type of <a href="Squash%20%28plant%29">squash</a> most often used as a <a href="winter%20squash">winter squash</a>. It is an <a href="Heirloom%20plant">heirloom</a>, predating 1820. A cultivar of "<a href="Cucurbita%20maxima">Cucurbita maxima</a>", it is closely related to the <a href="buttercup%20squash">buttercup squash</a>. It is typically 6 pounds when mature. Colors vary, but are often mottled in shades of orange, green, and white. The squash is used as both a <a href="winter%20squash">vegetable</a> and as an ornamental <a href="gourd">gourd</a>. Taste is similar to other "<a href="Cucurbita%20maxima">C. maxima</a>" cultivars, though "not as vibrant," "reminiscent to <a href="hazelnut">hazelnut</a>," and "coarse, watery and insipid." Known in the nineteenth century as "the most beautiful in color, and the most worthless in quality, of all the varieties of squash;" More recently, Ian Knauer, author of "The Farm", has described it as "nutty and sweet".
There are two varieties or cultivars:
